subject: Perl Advent Calendars
header: This week again, there were relatively few articles. I wonder if this is the silence before the ... Advent calendars? In case you don't know, every year, just before Christmas, several groups of Perl developers create Advent calendars, and publish one article every day. I already see two groups getting organized. See the links below, how you might help.

entries.title: Helios 2.60 Released
entries.text: Helios is a distributed job processing system. It's on CPAN, but it now also has its own web site linked from the article.

entries.title: Why PERL_UNICODE makes me SAD
entries.text: With a funny use of the acronym, David Golden explains what does the PERL_UNICODE flag do, and how can that might make things worse.

entries.title: The Curious Case of the Justifiable but Slow Singleton
entries.text: In the first part of his article chromatic shows his dislike how people took the ideas described in the Design Patterns book and followed them as if those were recommendations instead of descriptions. How it lead to a prolificiation of Singletons - (aka. global variables). Then he shows an example where a singleton can actually be useful.

entries.title: Its Time for Catalyst Advent!
entries.text: A call for people to write Catalyst-related articles for the Advent calendar. Let me emphasize, that John Napiorkowski is looking for both technical and non-technical articles. For example how using Catalyst is a good business decision.

entries.title: Perl Advent Calendar
entries.text: A couple of days ago Ricardo Signes sent out a call for help on the Perl Advent mailing list. I cannot link to that message, but you can check out the web site of the Perl Advent Calendar and see how you can write an article.

entries.title: Testing WebSockets from console
entries.text: The title might be a little misleading. Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) showed how to use the console utility that comes with Protocol::WebSocket to check and debuge the server side of the websocket.

entries.title: Filters with Template Toolkit
entries.text: Want to display prices in 4 different currencies? Want to make it easy for the person building the HTML to do this? Alberto Simões shows how.

chapters.title: Configuration Management - Deployment
chapters.header: I wonder if this area of the newsletter should actually be called 'DevOps'

entries.title: On the utility of Module::Build::CleanInstall
entries.text: As Joel Berger explains, when you upgrade a module, sometimes you want to make sure old files from the previous installations are all gone. This is what the Module::Build plugin accomplishes. There is something that looks similar in both major toolchains, but that is actually a complementary operation. Frankly, I wish this was also part of the toolchains and not some extra module.

entries.title: Deploying 'Half of CPAN' on Debian using Carton
entries.text: There is a tension between developer like Peter Makholm who would like to use recent versions of modules and system administrators who prefer the onese that are distributed by their vendor. In this case Debian. Carton can help in creating a list of modules with specific version numbers that can make it easier to use them on the production systems.

entries.title: Help Perl Project Layout Problem
entries.text: It is rare that you can see the issues a project - larger than a CPAN module - faces. That's why it is interesting to see how Joe Crotty is handling a project with several programming languages and various helper files and other assets involced.

entries.text: El equipo de Perl en español busca lectores y revisores técnicos. push @equipo, @colaboradores

entries.title: Boolean values in Perl
entries.text: I thought this will be a very boring part of the tutorial, but it turns out there is some serious confusion about boolean values is Perl. Actually it probably partially comes from people who arrive from other languages. Get confused. Implement their own 'true' and 'false' values in Perl and then others learn from them...
